review_text: Why is this the best Batman movie? The cinematography is INCREDIBLE. It is a master class in lighting and camera work. It gets visual inspiration from the comics, the video games, and movies like: Se7en, Taxi Driver, Silence of the Lambs, Prisoners and more. The acting is phenomenal. You forget it’s Pattinson, you forget it’s Colin Farrel, you forget it’s Paul Dano. Even Zoe Kravitz, who I think is mediocre, gives her best performance yet. Jeffry Wright is my favorite Gordon, which is hard because Gary Oldman was perfect. But the Batman & Gordon dynamic here is way more fun. The story is actually derived from actual comics (much of BATMAN EARTH ONE vol 2, with some The Long Halloween, Batman Year One, Court of Owls and Zero Year sprinkled in). The score is the best Bat music since 1989s Batman theme by Danny Elfman (except maybe Batman the Animated Series by Shirley Walker). It’s a dark, neo-noir detective story (Batman is the worlds greatest detective), and there’s real world and character building. Don’t listen to anyone about the costumes, they are directly inspired by the comics (Lee Bremejo’s art, as well as from Earth One and Year One), and meant to be more real and grounded (despite how everyone credits TDK for being “real”). This takes the comics and even inspo from the Adam West ‘66 Batman and makes it dark and gritty. Addressing the “wokeness”: yes there is one lame line about “white privileged a**holes”. It’s very out of place and I’m sure was demanded by Warner Bros & DC Comics to be shoehorned in. “Rich, corrupt a**holes” would have been more accurate and less insulting to a significant portion of the audience. BUT if you know how sickeningly woke those 2 companies are outside of this movie, this is NOTHING. And really, it doesn’t ruin anything. So Gordon is played by a black guy, it has zero affect on anything. He’s cast because he’s great in the role and there’s no hidden agenda in his character. Zoe looks exactly like Catwoman in YEAR ONE, so that point is also wrong. It’s not “liberal woke trash” as some crybabies are calling it. And trust me, I’d be the first to dismiss it if it was. THE ONLY criticism I have is that I wish they had committed to its grit and taken it 100% seriously, and made it rated R and gruesome… I know the studio wouldn’t allow that, but it feels very neutered when there’s all this implied gore we never see any blood. And there’s a couple kind of silly moments that are out of tone with how dark and serious a lot of it is. Again, ruins nothing for me… this is “in a perfect world” kinda stuff. Batman has to be accessible to young teens too, I get it… Haters gonna hate, this movie is THE BEST BATMAN. Watch it.

The Batman is a very good movie overall but it falls short in one place and feels a little weird in another. It has a comic book feel without spelling it out but fans will see the connections between the narration, world and plot-lines. They chose to saturate the film in black, red and orange hues which helps set the tone and creates a different, more serious atmosphere. Where I thought it fell short is while they're unraveling the Riddler's manifesto, Batman is always seen in the suit but unnecessarily so. This works against him and in fact, everytime Batman is in the suit and there's a humanizing moment, it works against him in the same way Bane's mask prevented us from seeing Bane's true mad genius in Dark Knight Rises. My impression is that this movie was a big departure from the previous iterations of the cartoony Batman, world and characters. Perhaps it's this cartoony world that viewers have come to love about Batman, is that they've grown attached to it and why this more realistic version of Batman has garnered so much negative reviews but I really think they should stick with it but they should aim to be more practical in some places like Batman doesn't always need to be in a suit except for when he's going to fight bad guys. I'd like to say this DC Movie is in-line with the Batman world with the ultra-realistic Joker, starring J. Phoenix, and all future movies that will be made with that form of realism for Batman should have been made clear for viewers. I think one way they could have done that is to have Batman doing the detective work without wearing the suit, which is a major part of the first third of the movie. Same could have gone for Catwoman, when we do see her. That would allow viewers to get a feel for the new Batman and his new world of Gotham, in the same way that J. Phoenix did for Joker. This is a good Batman but I think they over did it with the emphasis of "a Gotham city in peril" and the psychopathic elements of the main Villain, which became tired and maybe even a little weird, mid-way through and I felt what was being rehashed didn't need further analysis - how everyone in Gotham seemed to be affected by what was reported on the news, The Carmine and Catwoman stuff, and the "presence" of Batman when he enters the scene, almost seeming intimidating in his suit. It would have been better if these scenes were R. Pattinson wearing casual clothing and a trench coat. Perhaps he would have a tattoo of the bat symbol or a bat on his wrist or something to give the viewer the needed connection. Everything else, the mafia world, Batman and Catwoman were more personal and evolved, and the martial arts choreography. The actors were great and I think they pulled off what they set out to do: a Batman that was more true to the comics that was a little over the top in a couple places. It could have been a great movie but it's still a very good movie in many places. The second hour tends to drag since it rehashes a lot of ground covered in the first hour, which was fun and the third hour is also fun.

As for someone who has been a Batman fan since 1955, this movie was "different" I didn't find it to be a bad movie, but I didn't find it to be anything to crow about either. As far as Batman movies go, it was slow paced and rather dull. If you're hoping for a pretentious movie that aspires to be much more than a comic book adaptation, then this movie is probably just what you're looking for. If you're looking for a moody man in a Batman costume who rarely has anything even remotely like a real conversation with another human being, then this movie is for you. If you're hoping for an angry man filled with vengeance who is one step away from therapy or prison, then this Batman is for you. But if you're looking for a faithful adaptation of what Batman has been and meant to his loyal fans since the beginning, then this probably won't make you smile. As for those who rave about this adaptation of Batman, all I can say is that some people are much more easily impressed than others. This is a moody melodrama, and worth watching. But in my opinion, this is nowhere near the best or even one of the best Batman efforts that could have been done.

The tricky thing about reviving a long-lived franchise is, it’s always going to be compared to its predecessors. And, as the caped crusader goes, that history is awfully long and speckled. Tim Burton dealt with this when he helmed the 1989 iteration, dodging complaints that it was so fundamentally different from the Adam West camp of twenty years prior. Christopher Nolan fought an uphill battle in overcoming the damage inflicted by Joel Schumacher’s missteps. Now, in the wake of Ben Affleck’s turn beneath the cowl, Matt Reeves faces a different, but similar fight in justifying his vision of a spandex-clad detective in the crumbling urban decay. Reeves gives us a younger Batman, less seasoned and polished than the Kilmer/Clooney/Affleck years, but also not a rookie. This isn’t an origin story; this bat’s reputation has already been established in Gotham and he’s fostered a tenuous working relationship with certain members of the police force. He’s visible enough to draw the attention of a violent, counter-culture master criminal who addresses hints and clues like love letters and sprinkles them around his prolific crime scenes. But he lacks that grand, accomplished sense of supreme confidence: a patrolman who’s still learning his beat, he makes mistakes and takes lessons from them. Actually, he makes a *lot* of mistakes. This Batman is neither impervious in a fight nor unmatched in an intellectual sense. He often seems like he’s out of his depth, reacting and improvising to events beyond his control. That can be humanizing, but it also limits his aura. In terms of raw energy and dramatic appearances, this rendition ranks near the bottom. I might even call him dull. That’s a problem with the whole film, in fact. It has inspired and effective moments, isn’t demonstrably bad, but constantly feels clinical and lethargic. There’s very little dramatic spectacle, so I was never wowed. For all the boastful talk about emphasizing the detective aspect of his character, Batman himself doesn’t actually solve much. Alfred cracks most of the riddles, and when he’s eventually indisposed, the Riddler complains that his counterpart isn’t getting to the answers fast enough. Robert Pattinson’s take on the leading role is... okay. He looks the part while in costume, but often overacts, and his take on the brooding Bruce Wayne, as I’d feared, falls on the wrong side of the emo spectrum. Paul Dano’s Se7en-influenced Riddler is a fresh reimagining, but the conclusion of his story (or lack thereof) leaves an empty feeling. Hints and implications are dropped all over the place - about Gordon, the Penguin, Catwoman and other noteworthy rogues who shall remain nameless - but none go beyond the level of superficial winks. Batman and Robin’s Mister Freeze, for all his cheesy one-liners and bad costume effects, had a more cohesive, satisfying story than any of these characters. I don’t want to give the wrong impression. This isn’t a bad effort. I admire its influences, and its chutzpah for wearing them loudly on its chest. Gotham is dark and gritty, its corrupt politicians serving as an appropriate mirror to their real-life counterparts. The costumes and set designs look great. But, in a strange way, I feel that it tries too hard to match the execution of 2019’s Joker without really grasping what made that movie tick or why the two should be distinctive. Both are deathly serious, heavily visual, mood-reliant character pieces, but where Joker limits its iris to a small, tight group of characters, The Batman is overwhelmed by its cast. Joaquin Phoenix takes us on a private journey in the former film, and it’s meaningful when his arc is resolved. Pattinson, by comparison, never progresses beyond looking mopey in the rain.

This iteration of Batman does many things that I always wished the others had done. Firstly, it treats itself like a film rather than a superhero film. Even Nolan's trilogy, while it did a good job and I do greatly enjoy those films, felt a little hammy here and there and just didn't pack the cinematic punch that I tend to go for. This is a grim, slow burn murder mystery set in the Batman universe. It takes its time and lets things breathe, and this works wonderfully both for the characters and the overall atmosphere. Next, as mentioned, it's grim. What I've always loved about Batman is that, while the campier elements are indeed fun from time to time, the character and the lore lends itself so well to a more eerie horror based approach and I don't think we've really gotten that before, at least not for a whole film. The opening maybe half hour-ish is a perfect reflection of all of this. It sucks you in, gives you tingles down your spine, and doesn't let go. Yes, it's a longer film, and for me, at times that runtime is felt, though by the end I still wanted more. It sorta feels like you're binging new episodes of a favorite show and it's upsetting that there's only so much to chew on. Without rambling on for too long, I was initially just lukewarm on this the first time I saw it; I loved most of it, but the last act had issues for me; though having seen it a few more times, I've fallen in love with the whole film and I'm very excited to see where the director's trilogy plan goes. I'd also like to take a moment to show appreciation to the decision of showcasing a very lost, angry Bruce Wayne that hasn't figured out his playboy persona yet. It's something new to see him so stuck in his trauma that he just can't, and doesn't care to, be anything but Batman. It'll be interesting to see him grow that persona in future films... and there better be a lot of them, because this was just great. If I HAD to point at a negative, I'd say that I've got two and they're really just nitpicks on my end. The main villain had some moments in here that really made me crack up the first time I saw the movie and these moments still kinda get me. That's not to say the villain or the actor was bad. They're actually great. My sense of humor is just off the wall and certain mannerisms the character had just got me. And I feel like the movie reshot a few bits to be less violent for the PG-13 rating. When it's dark, it's REALLY dark, so you can spot a few scenes here and there where it's clear they were initially going to do something heavier, but backed off for the final product; a big one for me was a moment where Bats pretty much beat a guy to a pulp and when you see the result it almost looks like he'd only been slapped around a bit rather than... you know... having his face broken. But that's really it. Otherwise it's great and you should all see it. More please!

Matt Reeves’ 2022 film, “The Batman,” loosely adapts Jeph Loeb and Tim Sales’s story, “Batman: The Long Halloween.” It begins with the Batman (Robert Pattinson) in his second year of crime-fighting, putting this story in a chronologically similar setting as the comic while also referencing events from Frank Miller’s “Batman: Year One,” which itself inspired “Batman: Begins.” This film references events familiar to Batman fans without re-treading familiar territory. It introduces a different version of the Riddler, inspired by Zodiac, who targets corrupt political officials in the increasingly economically-stratified and corrupt Gotham. Pattinson’s Batman gets to demonstrate his detective skills, following clues and trying to figure out the crime, though the nature of the story means that he only catches up to the Riddler (Paul Dano) toward the end. Assisting him are Alfred Pennyworth (Andy Serkis), GCPD Lieutenant James Gordon (Jeffrey Wright), and Selina Kyle (Zoë Kravitz). They face the Gotham mob, represented by Oswald “Oz” Cobblepot/Penguin (Colin Farrell) and Carmine Falcone (John Turturro). Selina Kyle’s story with Falcone further draws upon the events of Loeb & Sales’s “Long Halloween” and “Catwoman: When in Rome.” Set early in the Batman’s career, this story shows a Batman who has not yet developed the Bruce Wayne persona that other actors use to show the dichotomy between Wayne/Batman. Reeves also balances the desire for gritty realism with more comic book elements, creating realistic gadgets and villains for Batman who are just across the line into fantasy and don’t use exposition to firmly ground them in reality. In this, Reeves captures the best parts of the comics he references while showing the influence of Christopher Nolan’s grounded “Dark Knight” trilogy. Furthermore, each actor perfectly fits their part and brings something that fills out the world or advances the story. The score by Michael Giacchino works particularly well to build the films atmosphere. Finally, this is one of only three live-action Batman films in which Batman realizes he can be more than a Dark Knight and symbol of fear (the other two are “Batman Forever” and “The Dark Knight Rises”). As the first in a planned series, this realization opens up interesting story possibilities for the forthcoming sequels. This Blu-ray/DVD combo pack includes the film on one disc of each as well as an extra Blu-ray disc containing the bonus features. These include a making-of documentary, deleted scenes with director Matt Reeves’s commentary, a breakdown of the car-chase sequence, a look at the creation of this iteration of the Batman compared to his predecessors, a look at how Zoë Kravitz got into character as Catwoman, and more.

irector Matt Reeves definitely leaves an impression with this. The opening, introducing Gotham and Batman (played by Robert Pattinson) is just an excellently realized work of cinema. Visually, The Batman really captures the feel of being in a city with some excellent scenery ranging from dirty streets to the fancy but antiquated areas. Bruce Wayne's place in particular, is a fantastically busy neo-gothic looking affair. Also, Reeves really went out of his way to make the city look populated. Has some of the most crowded extras scenes I've seen in a while. Must've been quite an endeavor to put together. This also has one of the most ambitious car chases put to screen. I've never seen a movie have a car chase in such congested, traditional city traffic. In fact, it feels a little too real like actual traffic accident situations and took me out of it a little. Also, this is the one scene where you question Batman's methods. This has excellent lightning with a lot of good use of city lights. I can often be be annoyed by films that are too darkly shot, but this one always feels like the shadows are always in the right place, accentuating the scenes. Michael Giacchino's soundtrack really helps the film's mood; very sweeping and moving. This film skips an origin story for or introduction to Batman. I think this might be the closest a live-action film has come to matching the feel of the comics (at least the more recent ones.) You just jump in with Batman, who's already been operating for two years and has already established a relationship with Lt. Gordon (Westworld's Jeffrey Wright). No live-action Batman film has ever focused on the detective side of the character as this. This is a straight-up mystery film mixed with a serial killer film and a crime film. The story, aided by the atmosphere of the piece, will keep your eyes glued. However, when you get down to it the film's basic concepts, the corruption and themed serial killer parts, aren't that original. Heck, the movie even reuses a couple plot points from the comics. This also repeats the idea from the first two Nolan films of Batman fighting against the established criminal underworld who have Gotham in their grip. Between this, the Nolan films, Gotham (the show if you're not familiar), and some of the animated films, including the recent The Long Halloween, I'm so tired of Batman stories reusing the same mob figures like Carmine Falcone (here played by John Turturro) and Sal Maroni. Do you realize that there have been two live-action movies with Carmine Falcone and none with the likes of such villains as Clayface, Mad Hatter, or Dr. Hugo Strange? If you ask someone for their top ten or five Batman villains, they're not going to say Carmine Falcone. Enough with the flipping Carmine Falcone and other mobsters stories, already!!! You're not paving any new ground!!! The movie didn't need to be three hours long. They could've easily cut down on the number of characters. Though I do like Zoe Kravitz's Catwoman and she has great chemistry with Batman, her subplot could've easily been cut. Understand that this is probably the darkest mainstream superhero movie put to screen. Things can get pretty unsettling, like even more unsettling than some of the Joker moments from The Dark Knight. (From a technical standpoint, I'm weirdly impressed with how they pulled this off with a PG-13 rating.) Cast is great in this. Though you may argue that they make Batman a little too brooding and his Bruce Wayne appearance a little too emo, Pattinson does one of the best jobs of portraying a human Batman who is determined to do his all against terrible odds and is an empathetic man beneath his stolid persona. Wright is definitely one of the Best Gordons with THE best relationship with a Batman. He's kinda Batman's sidekick in this. Andy Serkis, who I don't think anyone suspected would be playing the role, is one of the best Alfred Pennyworths, though he doesn't get much screent ime. He's become so known for motion capture performances, it's nice to see how good a performer he is just by himself. Recommend. I wouldn't rank this as high as the Nolan trilogy or even Batman Returns. I felt those movies did a better job with plotting and characters. Also, the length, heavy tone, and the fact that the plot points aren't that original, hurts replay value. Still, this is a very strong, visually impressive, well-acted entry that does catch your attention.

The noir elements of The Batman aren't just relegated to visuals, the dialog and story itself is very noir detective. Some of these lines could be in a Humphrey Bogart flick. While some will find it boring, to me it gives the film a sort of cool sheen to it. I am Batman comic fan for most of my life and so it's refreshing to finally see a proper detective story in live action. The more grounded version actually refers a lot to the Batman Earth One series, which to me is also cool. Some of the 'emo' here can be hokey. "I don't care about THAT" is about as corny as Anakin Skywalker's "I hate sand" quote. But it's really not distracting. And the absolute best part of this film is that is, indeed, THE Batman. It is not 45 minutes of Bruce Wayne figuring out what he wants to be. Yes it's long, it gets slow in some parts, but it's probably the best Batman next to Nolan's trilogy and 1989. Zack Snyder fans will probably hate it, since there isn't some cartoony CGI battle at the end. If I had to critique the story, while it's a noir thriller/detective story through and through, it's not a mystery per se. As the pieces fall into place, there's no grand twist, nothing to solve. You know who the villain is, it's a matter of the story letting itself unfold to understand why they are doing what they do.

review_text: First of all, I normally do not review Special Features on a Video Release. I am usually interested in only the film itself, and I must admit that I rarely view the Special Features on Home Video. The Batman is a wonderful exception. Each of the Special Features on the 4k / Blu Ray Edition of The Batman were positively thrilling. I received the package today, and spent over two hours viewing the Special Features. The multiple mini-Documentaries - one of which is over fifty minutes long - did a superb job of explaining the Director's and Writer's vision behind The Batman. And the deleted scenes, which can be viewed with or without the Director’s commentary, are every bit as interesting as promised. As for the film, well, today I saw it for the third time – once in a Theatre on Opening Day, once on HBO Max and now on my very own 4k Disc. This version of Batman, THE Batman, is a take on the character that has not been explored in any Film before. As illustrated in the numerous One and Two Star reviews here, this iteration of the character has more than its share of detractors. To those who are not happy with The Batman I say, walk away and wait - there will undoubtedly be other versions of Batman in the future, and hopefully one more to your liking. As for me, I loved every satisfying minute of it, and I expect to view it many more times. I have a friend whose opinion I value greatly, who saw it eight times in a Movie Theatre. I don’t really know what some people were expecting. Batman has had so many different treatments that I marvel that the creative team on this film were able to come up with such fresh ideas. This is not The Dark Knight (thank goodness) and not something that Tim Burton would dream up. This is a wholly new and altogether unique take on a Vigilante / Hero that has been done to death. Yes, it’s the darkest, most humorless, grim version of The Batman ever done. Bravo! I found so much in this film to be drawn into, and so much to analyze, that even after three viewings, I haven't quite been able to absorb it all. The plot twists had my brain spinning, trying to keep up. This Batman is not for stupid people. And with each separate viewing, I experienced some of the greatest terror even unleashed by a villain in a Superhero movie. I grew up reading Detective Comics in the 1960’s and, director Matt Reeves and lead actor Robert Pattinson have given us a story that fits in with my understanding of the character more than any other film or TV take on Batman that I’ve ever seen. Not that any of the past films were bad (ok, a few were awful) but this version brings out an aspect of The Batman that I have always treasured. To me, Batman was always a serious Comic Book combination of three things 1) The World’s Greatest Detective 2) The World’s Greatest Acrobat and 3) The World’s Greatest Martial Arts Expert. It is the Detective portion of the character that has been ignored up ‘til now, and that has always been my favorite feature of Batman. This film brings that quality to the forefront. In addition, many of those who didn’t like it seem to overlook that this Batman is in his second year as a crimefighter, still very young, still somewhat naïve, and still finding his way. The Police and Gotham's Citizens have not yet learned to trust him. In one already iconic scene, The Batman comes to the rescue of a straphanger being terrorized by a gang of young punks. After the bad guys are defeated, the victim continues to cower and says to The Batman, "Please don't hurt me". That is a brilliant way to illustrate how green The Batman is in this Film. Mr. Reeves has brought us a tale that is definitely noir, definitely dark, serious and, above all, creepy, thanks to the brilliant portrayal of The Riddler by Paul Dano. Mr. Dano is an actor I have had my eyes on for several years now, ever since his magnificent characterization of a sleezy Preacher in There Will Be Blood. The storyline is twisted and The Riddler's appearances terrifying. I found myself on the edge of my seat wondering what surprise was coming next, and just when I thought it was resolved we get another twist and then another. The two-hour and fifty-six minute run time flew by for me, and I’m really sorry that so many people didn’t seem to get it. Over at IMDB, where good films get taken far more seriously than they do by the “Critics” at Amazon, The Batman has an average rating of Eight out of Ten Stars. Go figure. This is not a Batman for fans of Harry Potter and Jurassic Park. The cast is uniformly wonderful and everyone involved in this film has given their all. Besides Robert Pattinson, Zoe Kravitz, Jeffrey Wright, Colin Farrell, Paul Dano, John Turturro, Andy Serkis, and Peter Sarsgaard, even the actors playing minor parts were all outstanding. I could write for hours and not get tired of praising the many achievements of this serious, refreshing Film, but for now let me just say that I, for one, highly recommend The Batman and my rating is a full Five Stars. Brilliant!

review_text: The Batman is yet another live-action take on Batman, yet one that is much different than what has come before. This film forgoes doing the origin story that has been done multiple times and jumps into Batman's second year as a vigilante. He is working with Lieutenant Gordon who brings him in to investigate a series of murders involving high-ranking Gotham officials, with the killer leaving riddles for Batman at the scene of each kill. The story is much more of an origin story for the rogue's gallery of villains and is adapted heavily from the year one and year two comics. The casting of the movie was (as always) controversial with Robert Pattinson playing Bruce Wayne/Batman, Zoe Kravits playing Selina Kyle/Catwoman, Paul Dano playing The Riddler, Collin Farrell playing Penguin, Jeffrey Wright playing Jim Gordon, Andy Serkis playing Alfred, and John Turturro playing Carmine Falcone. Of course, Pattinson's casting was a subject of much debate (as has most every casting choice for Batman since Keaton landed the role in the late 1980s). Pattinson was best known for his roles in the Twilight series (which even he admits were not that good) and as Cedric Diggory in Harry Potter. I think most people complaining about his casting either were not aware of his other work, in which he has shown his acting chops or just liked to complain. But, he, and the rest of the cast, did a great job with their characters. Farrell was unrecognizable both in look and voice as Penguin (he was really just a secondary character in the movie) and Dano, who to this point was probably best known as a side character in the movie Girl Next Door and from his role in There Will be Blood, was awesome as The Riddler. And, Barry Keoghan was great in his minute or so at the end clearly playing an early version of The Joker (but credited as being the unseen Arkham inmate). The movie looks and sounds great in UHD. The 4K set is actually a three-disc set. The UHD disc and one of the regular Blu-Ray discs just has the movie itself, and the second regular Blu-Ray disc has all the special features and extras. The extras include several short behind-the-scenes featurettes that range from a couple of minutes to about 10 minutes in length. The main feature is an almost hour-long making-of documentary which spans pretty much the entire filming process and shows how the covid pandemic really impacted how the film was made. Then there are a couple of deleted scenes that you can watch with or without director commentary. Overall, the movie is great. I do think it is a bit long and could have been cut down for time. That said, I think most of the scenes that did end up in the final cut of the film worked, so aside from a couple of scenes at the very end of the film, I think it would have been hard to pick what to remove. I like the fact that Batman is not yet fully formed in this movie and he is still trying to figure out how to be Batman, without really caring about being Bruce Wayne. It is also interesting to see him operate out in the daylight while literally carrying the Batsuit around in a duffel bag slung over his shoulder. The movie has a feel that is much more similar to Nolan's trilogy of movies than it does to the Burton or Schumacher movies, without being a carbon copy of what Nolan did with his. The movie has an old-school film noir crime/detective story feel to it and is extremely well-acted. Definitely worth watching and investing in the disc for those who still get the physical discs.

review_text: **I would advise against watching the 4K UHD version of this film (either the digital download or the 4K UHD disc) on a 4K TV. Watching the 4K UHD download/disc on a regular (non-4K) TV is fine, as is watching a regular (non-4K UHD) presentation on a 4K TV. But don't watch a 4K UHD copy on a 4K TV.** The 4K UHD transfer is sharp and immaculate, and therein lies the problem. A moody, noir thriller should be have a visual tone that matches the film’s mood. That visual tone is almost totally lost in 4K UHD format because the image is brighter and full of significantly more visual detail. It’s like walking through a haunted house with the lights on. What you gain in clarity and detail you lose in atmosphere. The sharper the details the more it resembles the dreaded “TV soap opera effect”. It really does feel like you’re watching television instead of a movie. I even read one reviewer's comment that the image is so hyper-realistic it looks like you're immersed in in and are watching a play. 4K UHD, which can make concert videos and nature documentaries look stunning and awesome, doesn’t always lend itself to narrative fiction. The increased sharpness and brightness blurs the line between fiction and “you are there” reality. And it’s pretty disconcerting to watch. I saw “The Batman” four times in the theaters and the visual presentation was as perfect as it could be. But watching it at home on 4K UHD is a major shift, and not for the better. I’m hoping the regular Blu-ray with its content-appropriate resolution will more closely match the theatrical experience when the Blu-ray is watched on a 4K TV. When I watched the 4K UHD digital download on my phone and on my iPad - neither of which has a 4K screen - everything looked fine. There’s nothing even remotely scary or intense about “The Batman” in 4K UHD. The image is too bright and pristine. It kills the mood. Like I said, it’s like touring a haunted house with the lights on. You can see too much. There’s nothing to set the mood of dread or tension. Bottom line: the human eye does not see the real world in hyper-realistic UHD, which is why seeing narrative fiction in UHD looks a little "off" sometimes. Your brain knows you're watching fiction but your eyes are trying to tell your brain you're watching real life. So it makes for a disconcerting experience. If you want to buy the 4K UHD version of this film, i think you'll enjoy it more if you view it on a screen that is NOT scaled for 4K UHD resolution. I kid you not. Again, this is mainly relevant for fiction. If you're watching nature documentaries like "Planet Earth", actual real-life events like "Free Solo" or "The Barkley Marathons", or a well-shot concert video that wasn't shot in soft diffusion like David Mallet used to do, then 4K material on a 4K UHD TV is fantastic!! But for narrative fiction please be more careful.

Most superhero movies, especially the bigger IP's, are power fantasies. There's nothing wrong with that, it can be cathartic to watch someone beat up the bad guys and live vicariously through these heroes we grew up reading and or watching. The Batman (or Battinson as I like to call it) starts off this way, but we learn pretty quickly that there's a whole lot more to the film than seeing the bad guys get their comeuppance. There's a surprising level of introspection in this power fantasy. When both the heroes and villains use violence as a way to achieve their goals, what separates them really? I suppose if you just want to disconnect from reality for nearly three hours and avoid introspection this could be a turn off, but I don't think we can give the Nolan/Bale movies the distinction of being the most "realistic" Batman movies anymore. Those films are still great, but they're very comic book-y compared to this movie. Technically speaking the direction, acting, cinematography, sound effects, and score are fantastic. As a music fan, sometimes using popular music in a film can ruin it for me and make me roll my eyes. I actually started off a little lukewarm on the film's use of Nirvana's "Something in the Way," but it really grew on me. The tone just fits. Pattinson as Battinson (couldn't help myself) works really well for the film. Batman is not well psychologically speaking, and he was absolutely perfect in the role of an unhinged vigilante with good intentions. I was concerned at first, as I only knew him from Twilight, but this guy has a lot of range as we can see in movies like The Lighthouse. The Riddler is more threatening than he's ever been, and though some people like to drag Paul Dano on his performance with the mask off, I think it fits. His goals are sympathetic to anyone disappointed in politicians and their broken promises, but he is also not psychologically sound enough to take the law into his own hands. The Batman/Riddler dichotomy is the same point The Dark Knight tried to make with Heath Ledger's legendary Joker, that they're two sides of the same coin, but this film pulled it off better to me because it actually made Batman question himself and change his outlook. Which is what growth looks like. Bale's Batman didn't really grow much throughout that series, and I'd argue that he's the most boring character in the series. Batman films tend to focus more on the villains than Batman himself, as he's mostly just stoic and one-note. This is a true Batman film, and I can't wait to see more from Matt Reeves and Robert Battinson.

review_text: Well, the Snyderverse never really took off, and that’s a shame, so it is back to square one, and that means we get a whole new incarnation of DC’s most fascinating top tier super hero, Batman. This new version is directed by Matt Reeves, who directed CLOVERFIELD, a film of which I am a big fan, and is simply titled THE BATMAN. This time the Caped Crusader is going solo as there is not a mention of Superman, Wonder Woman, The JLA, or any other hero of the DC universe. Reeves’ film is a stripped down, grim and gritty saga set in Gotham City very early in the career of millionaire Bruce Wayne turned vigilante. It’s dark, literally, as most scenes take place at night, and black it the primary color. The skies always appear to be cloudy, the better for the bat signal to appear, and rain is falling half the time. This is another film that can be considered a literal descendant from Martin Scorsese’s TAXI DRIVER, not to mention Ridley Scott’s BLADE RUNNER. I thought other primary influences are David Fincher’s SEVEN, and James Wan’s SAW. There’s also a noticeable lack of humor in the script, which portrays Gotham as an urban hellhole, where street thugs prey almost at will upon citizens while organized crime gets rich off dealing drugs with the help of a police force mostly on the take. Some will find all this darkness, literal and otherwise, to be pretentious, but I think it succeeds by building a world where a masked vigilante is the only salvation. Where I also think THE BATMAN succeeds amazingly well is when it leans into the Caped Crusader as “the world’s greatest detective.” The basic plot of the film concerns the pursuit of The Riddler—the film’s chief Big Bad—a serial killer targeting the mayor, the chief of police, the district attorney, and other authority figures in Gotham while leaving riddles at each crime scene for Batmen. These riddles are clues to not only the motive behind The Riddler’s reign of terror, but to the larger corruption in Gotham, a big picture that comes to include the Wayne family. Along the way, Batman encounters Selena Kyle, a hostess at an underworld controlled night club who moonlights as the burglar known at Catwoman; club operator Oswald Cobblepot, the gimp also known as The Penguin; Carmine Falcone, the crime boss everyone works for in Gotham. Helping Batman is detective Jim Gordon, his only ally on a wary and suspicious police force; this is first Batman film to show a fractious relationship between Gotham’s champion vigilante and law enforcement, and it adds to the film enormously. Lurking behind them all is a masked murderer who shows no mercy. There are a couple of well staged set piece action scenes. The best is a terrifically staged car chase between the Batmobile and a fleeing Penguin through oncoming traffic, and an encounter in a pitch dark hallway between Batman and some mobsters where the only illumination comes from the flash of automatic weapons firing. How is Robert Pattinson in the title role? He’s moody and broody enough to make a good and imposing Batman, which is necessary to make the film work, but his Bruce Wayne (who doesn’t get much screen time) needs way more fleshing out. Pattinson never smiles, which suits the film’s mood, but he does have real chemistry with Zoe Kravitz’s Catwoman, whose strong presence is a good balance with the Caped Crusader. Paul Dano’s Riddler doesn’t show his face until late in the film, but he makes a quit convincing psycho. Jeffrey Wright is a commanding Jim Gordon, while John Turturro is appropriately slimy as Falcone. My favorite is an unrecognizable Colin Ferrall as The Penguin, a member of the rogue’s gallery we haven’t seen onscreen since Danny DeVito’s grotesque in Tim Burton’s BATMAN RETURNS, and of the two, I much prefer Ferrall’s snarling bottom feeding criminal. Andy Serkis is quite capable as Alfred. And that is the Carver twins as the muscles who man the door at Cobblepot’s club. In a good film, the musical score is a character in its own right, and that can truly be said about Michael Giacchino’s work on THE BATMAN, especially in the way he works in Nirvana’s “Something in the Way.” At three hours, THE BATMAN is a sit. I think a good twenty minutes could easily have been cut from it. As in all comic book films, there is some exposition heavy dialogue that can be clunky. And I can easily see where this film is not every Batman fan’s cup of tea; it has way much more in common with Todd Phillips’ THE JOKER than anything made by Burton or Joel Schumacher, not to mention the comic books written by Bob Kane and Bill Finger. Batman has been around a long time now, and when it comes to adaptations, I think we’ve gotten the hero to fit the times, starting with Adam West on the old ‘60s TV show, a series steeped in Boomer irreverence, to the Super Friends of long ago Saturday mornings, to the films of Burton, Schumacher, Christopher Nolan, and Zach Snyder, which in some way reflected the pop culture and the social tensions of past decades. Now Matt Reeves gives us a Batman for the 2020s. I like the way he leans into the theme of a city where the citizens have been betrayed and exploited by the elites and those in authority, and now the monsters they’ve created are coming for them. I’ll concede that it’s not an original approach, but it is a strong one with many storytelling possibilities. And where does this incarnation of Batman go next? Well, I was most intrigued by a brief appearance by Barry Keoghan, credited only as “unseen Arkham prisoner,” who tells The Riddler that people love a comeback story, and who has a very distinctive laugh.

The Batman is the first Batman movie, starting with the 1989 version, that I did not see in the theaters. There were a few different reasons but the final nail in the coffin was probably the nearly three hour running time. That running time is going to be pretty rough if you’re not loving Matt Reeves directing style because this movie moves SLOW. There is a scene early on where The Batman is at a crime scene and it’s clear that Reeves is in no hurry to move on to the next scene. This is where an editor would generally slice the scene in half, but I was personally enjoying it all. It’s a throwback to older movies where they would stay on a scene far longer. These days, movies just jump as fast as possible to keep everything rolling. I would say that this is the most realistic Batman movie yet. The Tim Burton and Joel Schumacher films were obviously pure fantasy. The Christopher Nolan films were much more grounded in reality with the plots being the most fantastic elements. In The Batman, even the plot of political corruption is entirely believable. I am very happy to say that there is no origin story in this film since everyone knows Batman’s origin. In this film, Batman has been operating for a couple of years. There is nothing related to Batman putting together his costume or testing his equipment, he’s already well established in Gotham City and feared by criminals. This also appears to be his first experience with a super criminal. If the movie falls short, I’d say it’s in the plot. The Riddler is murdering people, sending riddles to The Batman with each murder. Although The Batman is excellent at solving the riddles (he is more of a detective in this movie than previous ones), it doesn’t really help him to prevent future murders or even to capture The Riddler. It feels more like The Batman is just an observer to The Riddler’s crimes. Even when The Batman uses his deductive skills to discover The Riddler’s master plan, it’s all for naught as The Batman is almost entirely an observer while The Riddler’s plan plays out. He does leap into action, but The Riddler’s plan works almost flawlessly. I would also add that The Riddler’s entire motivation gets rather muddled by the end of the movie. It’s almost as if the writer started to panic that The Riddler might come off as the hero of the story, so they needed a quick reverse course. I’d say that the strength of the movie is in the casting, acting and dialogue. This is a very well-crafted movie. The problems are in a rather forgettable and somewhat illogical plot. I also kind of wished the Riddler’s costume bore at least some resemblance to his comic costume. The Penguin also bears only the slightest resemblance to his comic book self. There are some great moments in the film, but I found the climax underwhelming. Finally, I’d say that this film perhaps borrows a few too many elements from previous films. I could have sworn Pattinson had said this would be his only Batman film, but I guess they have given the green light to a sequel with all the cast signed, including Pattinson. I’m absolutely on board with revisiting this world. The end of the film definitely sets up a sequel. I cannot see how this new Batman franchise could possibly integrate with DC Extended Universe and I hope they don’t even try. I can’t even imagine this being a younger version of the Ben Affleck Batman. The closest film I can see to this one is the 2019 Joker, and I don’t see a reason to try and join the two. I particularly enjoyed Michael Keaton and Christian Bale as Batman and I’m not sure where I would rank Pattinson, even in relation to Affleck, but I did enjoy his performance immensely. I’d say that Nolan’s trilogy is still the gold standard but The Batman is a nice start and I look forward to seeing where it goes.

At this point in time, superhero movies have flooded Hollywood, most notably with the Marvel Cinematic Universe, leaving DC's live action filmography having to play major catch up. While they've been starting to make a few strides in branching out to featuring other characters in their history, it would seem that Batman is the number one crime fighter they constantly fall back on. And while I'm a huge fan of the character, even I was initially on the fence of seeing yet ANOTHER film with him when this newest installment was announced. But after good word of mouth, I made the trek to theaters to see this next incarnation of the Dark Knight.....and was completely blown away. Taking place during just the second year of Batman's crime fighting career, the Dark Knight vigilante has made a name for himself in Gotham City; primarily using fear to subdue and deter criminals. While he has the full support and friendship of Commissioner Gordon, the rest of the GCPD are more than leery around him---even more so when Gordon gets Batman directly involved in helping him solve the murder of a mayoral candidate. It doesn't take them long to figure out that a serial killer calling himself 'The Riddler' is behind the brutal crime, with the insane murderer leaving behind a trail of deranged puzzles for our heroes to solve, hinting at who his next victims will be. But the farther Batman goes down the rabbit hole, the more he begins to uncover an entire network of corrupt businessmen, politicians, and policemen; all of whom are manipulating various aspects of the city for their own gain. With the help of Gordon, as well as a former sex worker-turned cat burglar named Selina Kyle, Batman will have to utilize all his gadgets and wits to thwart the Riddler and see just how far the conspiracy goes. And in the process, he just may find out that what Gotham really needs is not an avatar for vengeance, but a symbol for hope and justice. I felt bad for Robert Pattinson back when he was announced to play our main hero, since it seems many people just can't get over his sparkly vampire days of "Twilight". I'm hoping this movie will finally put those naysayers to rest, because he's a phenomenal actor who completely disappears into the role of the Dark Knight. He says a lot with very little. He actually doesn't talk a whole lot, and expresses most of his inner emotions and thoughts with his actions and, most notably, his eyes. The movie does an excellent job of showing how and why Batman is considered the world's greatest detective. There's plenty of scenes of him just quietly and meticulously looking over evidence and other tiny details in a room. And while he's usually one step ahead of everyone, the movie's careful to also not depict him as some ridiculous super genius who's perfect at everything. Quite the opposite. There's plenty of times where he screws up or interprets a clue wrong, and half of the fun of the film is trying to solve the case along with the characters. The film has faith in the audience that they'll be smart enough to pick up on these details and not have to be spoon fed information. This is clearly early in Batman's career as a crime fighter. (The movie even points out we're only in Year Two.) Gordon trusts him, but he's still at odds with the rest of the police force. The Batmobile is basically just a beefed up car; fairly indestructible, but nothing too elaborate. He has a few gadgets, but nothing like the seemingly endless supply of swiss army knives he pulls from his Tardis-deep utility belt in past incarnations. He's a competent fighter, but it's nothing stagey or flashy. His punches are calculating and quick--meant to take down a target swiftly the way a real fight would actually play out. Basically, without losing his comic book-y essence, this is, arguably, the most realistic take on Batman you'll ever see. Special mention also goes to the cinematography, in particular, how lighting and shadows were used. The way scenes were shot really put you in the shoes of the people who get snuck up on by Batman. I was constantly scanning dark spots in a room, wondering if and when Batman was going to appear, and nine times out of ten, I'd guess wrong. And much like the criminals, you don't fully see him until it's too late. This is easily the best depiction of Batman's ninja skills that I've ever seen. (Weirdly enough, this movie manages to out-ninja "Batman Begins", which had actual ninjas in it.) I don't think I'm giving anything away in saying that the Riddler is the main villain (the trailer pretty much gives it away). However, the mystery doesn't stem from trying to figure out who he is (any comic fan can tell you that). The mystery and suspense comes from trying to deduce what his main goal is, why he's doing what he's doing, and who the next victims are going to be. He's incredibly scary (and is obviously heavily based off the Zodiac Killer). Even scarier is that when his grand scheme is finally fully revealed, you almost find yourself agreeing with him, though of course, he and Batman's methods of trying to take down city-wide corruption are light years apart. I don't want to spoil much else, but there ARE multiple villains in this; probably the most ever in a single Batman film, and yet, it doesn't feel cluttered at all. Every single character, hero and villain, has a purpose for being here, and every single one of them are interesting and/or entertaining to watch. At no point did I ever get bored when the plot veered off to a new person. It constantly leaves you guessing which people are on the take and how deep does the corruption go? On the subject of characters, this is easily the best on screen depiction of Catwoman ever. Her backstory is incredibly interesting, and it makes complete sense why she also goes down a vigilante path and how she has the skills that she does. She's not just shoehorned into the plot so Bruce can have a love interest. She and Batman are practically equals and pretty much partners by the end. On a related note, it's really nice to see Batman and Commissioner Gordon working so well together. In most other depictions, he's regulated to turning on the Bat-Signal, giving some information here and there, but otherwise letting Batman do all the heavy work. Here, he's basically practically Batman's Robin, with the two constantly exchanging and comparing notes and helping one another; sometimes outright saving each other. Finally, this movie decided to take the "Spiderman: Homecoming" route and begin the story with Batman already firmly established, with only a few backstory details scattered here and there. The rest, you can easily figure out on your own via the dialogue and actions. This film isn't the origin of how Bruce Wayne becomes Batman, but rather, him figuring out how to become a BETTER Batman. He begins the story believing that taking vengeance and striking fear into criminals will clean up the city streets. But when crime and violence only seems to rise, he realizes that, while scaring bad guys helps a little, it's not doing much to give the rest of the citizenry any hope. And by story's end, he may come to discover what he has to do to become the type of superhero that Gotham really needs. This was one of the most refreshing takes on Batman that I've seen in years. It's basically a crime drama with capes, and stays grounded in relative realism without losing the things we love about the character. I can't wait to see what other stories can be told in this new film universe.

review_text: Director Matt Reeves has brought his take to the world’s greatest detective (apologies to Sherlock Holmes). Reeve’s Batman is hardly Bruce Wayne at all but a thoroughly human man-child introvert irrevocably scarred by the death of his parents. The Batman is, first and foremost, a vigilante fighting to brutalize Gotham’s criminal element but in a close second he is a master detective and it is this egg that Reeves sits on, broods over, and hatches over most of the film. That the Batman is brilliant with an unwavering eye to detail is deftly shown; also that he is young and fallible and so a bit more vulnerable than many of the other cinematic Bat portrayals. The end of the film which turns into a mildly raucous superhero actioner ends up feeling out of place, almost tacked on, but narratively works as a devious pay-off and a too real for the real world telling of horrors that may yet still play out. In fact the intensity of this film, especially in how the characters are studied from angles including the heinous Riddler, comes across as horrifying and not for the younger set as it is simply too…real. This is yet another superhero film that, because of Batman’s history, will be trotted out before children and impressionable youngsters but it should be rated R due to its subject matter. It’s a good movie but it’s closer to “Seven” than “Justice League” in tone, feel, and story. It’s a good movie whereas, say the should have been R rated “Venom: Let There Be Carnage” in all its meanness and crudity had bad acting, “The Batman” has some great acting almost entirely across the board. The police, the politicians, the villains (especially Colin Farrell’s turn as crime boss Penguin), and the anti-hero (Catwoman/ Selina Kyle played by a sharp Zoe Kravitz), even when they’re not given a lot to do they do it well or exceedingly well. Robert Pattinson does a decent job as he broods and broods for days. He’s an odd choice to play Bruce Wayne/ Batman and he does a good job but he’s still an odd choice and doesn’t really fit the part. Still, that doesn’t hurt the film (the ending of the film hurts the film where Batman has an epiphany and realizes that he needs to be a hero and “steps into the light” which is at odds with the entire tone of the film). There is a promise, or a tease at least in the trailers, and that is that the Cat and the Bat will have a bit of a sizzling relationship and unfortunately there couldn’t be less chemistry between Pattinson and Kravitz as a square peg has with a round hole. That’s another failing of the film, but Kravitz’s Catwoman is compelling and she overshadows everyone else in just about every scene she’s in. Maybe we’ll get another movie out of this one: The Catwoman! One can dream.

I've watched Batman media for a long time, ever since the first cartoons. I appreciated the cartoons, so when movies started coming out, I watched them, thinking that I'd get the same Batman I was used to: dry, oddly aimed humor, but focused on sympathetic justice when allowed. Unfortunately, movies put out a "dark, gritty batman" that I just didn't like. They didn't feel right. Now THIS Batman? I love. There was no way a man could be a caped crusader at night and still somehow be a lady-killing, smooth talking billionaire in the daytime. Bruce could only ever be an exhausted, socially stunted creature who comes crawling out from the depths of his batcave to wear sunglasses in his living room amidst the remnants of his emo personality. He WOULD have a bass and several large speakers tucked around gothic architecture, he WOULDN'T know how to talk to a woman, he WOULD gloomily tell the man that raised him that he isn't his father. Now sure, this movie is long. Too long. They definitely could have trimmed the fat around some of the scenes, especially the opening scene. However, I've rewatched this movie several times over and I find something new each time. It's enjoyable! I appreciate all the characters and the parts they play. Its refreshing to actually like Batman when I usually root for the villain in these kinds of movies. The Riddler is actually disconcerting, like a true villain. It was nice to see a villain, a real villain that Batman had to struggle against. Robert Pattison is excellent in this role. I wasn't a fan before, but now I can't see the role being played by anyone else. He's intimidating as Batman and delightfully creepy as Bruce. And to those who complained about Bruce not being extremely buffed out...why would he be? He's a brawler, a fast and lethal fighter. He's got to be lean for that. All that bulk would have only slowed him down. It just WORKS. Anyways, this movie is a 10/10. It's a superhero movie that doesn't grate on the senses. It's a visual treat with fun characters along the way. Also the car chase scene is pretty much the best scene in the entire movie. I love that car. I'd let that car run over me. Watch this movie.

Possible spoilers. I had to ask myself, do I need another Batman movie? Especially after director Christopher Nolan’s magnificent “Dark Knight” trilogy. As it turns out, yes is the answer based on this latest iteration from director and co-writer (with Peter Craig), Matt Reeves. Reeves, you may recall was the guy behind the excellent last 2 “Planet of the Apes” reboots. Hell, I remember him from the “Felicity” TV series. This Batman is as far away from “Felicity” as you can get. If you thought Nolan’s films were dark, wait until you see this one. Every scene is at night and it’s raining all the time in Gotham City (A good reason to get the 4K version). Robert Pattinson is a perfect choice for the latest caped crusader, his second year in the job as I recall. Crime is rampant as usual, and The Batman/Bruce Wayne is in a deep funk because he doesn’t seem to be making much headway fighting it. He helps us understand his mental state in a voice-over narration which seems to solidify Reeves desire to make this a modern-day noir. A genre I love. A surge of serial killings by someone who calls himself The Riddler (Paul Dano) gets everyone’s attention including detective, James Gordon (Jeffrey Wright), a Batman confidant. Why? Those being targeted are high ranking politicos in Gotham, including the mayor (Rupert Penry-Jones) running for re-election. The Riddler leaves little greeting cards for The Batman that includes clues as to why and who the next target might be. The Batman is very good at deciphering riddles. In addition to Gordon, a few other comic book regulars are here. The Penguin/Oz is played by an unrecognizable Colin Farrell. He is still just a middle manager in the crime world headed by Carmine Falcone (John Turturro). Catwoman/Selina Kyle (Zoe Kravitz) is the best thing in the movie, providing just the right mix of wink-wink humor, badassery and sexiness. For once The Bat’s sensory perception finds romantic possibilities however restrained. Pattinson and Kravitz are great together in their scenes. I was hoping for more. Maybe later. After a couple killings, you can see that the disturbed Riddler feels that he and Batman are both looking for justice in Gotham. After all, when the Batman is asked who he is, he says “Vengeance.” The Batman confesses to Alfred (Andy Serkis), the Wayne family’s long-time butler/sergeant at arms that he no longer cares whether he lives or dies. In a scene early in the film, Nirvana’s song “Something in the Way” provides a perfect tone for The Batman’s sense of helplessness after watching a young boy finding that his father has been murdered. The song is reprised at the end of the film when he rescues the boy from floodwaters. The soundtrack is based on Michael Giacchino’s score. In addition to Nirvana the soundtrack features a Beethoven piano concerto and “Ave Maria” by Schubert to go along with some club music from Baauer, Corvad and Patrick Topping & Kevin Saunderson. The music stands out like a prominent character in the film. There are plenty of scenes of the Batman facing off against terrible odds including an end of the film wowzer. His Batmobile is a nitro-charged V-8 that doesn’t look like something off the shelf. Bruce Wayne’s personal car is a mint 1963 Corvette Stingray, black of course, that he drives to a funeral. If this all sounds incredibly cool, it is. It all adds to the allure, Reeves sees in the film’s setting and characters. So, what keeps this from being a perfect film and the equal of those from Nolan? I already mentioned that I wanted more of The Bat and The Cat. The film is way too long at about 3 hours. I would have cut some of the The Riddler’s rants. There are also at least 2 false endings. Quibbles aside this is a great Batman film and certainly one of the best films of the year. Highly recommended.

This is a more dark and foreboding take on Batman. It explores the mental, emotional, and physical tolls that being the Batman takes on Bruce Wayne, more so than in the previous trilogy by Nolan. It laid bear the depravity and corruption of Gotham City which in turn require the Batman. It also showed how inequality can motivate different people to escalating levels of violence based on their own skewed viewpoints, not unlike what we see in many societies today. Robert Pattinson was good as Batman, not perfect but I do hope he has a chance to reprise this role! It's hard to compete with Michael Keaton but yeah... Overall I think he understood the toll of being Batman and the internal struggle he has in wanting to save the city and reform Gotham to the point it doesn't need Batman and actually having to do what he does as Batman. From my viewpoint Pattinson was able to translate that to the screen. It also explored the sadistic nature of The Riddler, it bordered on the level of sinisterism, mania, and psychosis found in real life serial killers. Paul Dano fit the roll of the Riddler very well. The interactions with the other Arkham prisoner (that we can only assume is the Joker) was a nice little wrinkle. I felt that Zoe Kravitz as Selina Kyle/Catwoman was a superb pick although her actual catwoman costume was lacking. I get that there are limitations due to the current issues facing the world right now but come on costume dept. No offense to her as an actress but she looked like Dumb Donald from the Fat Albert cartoons from the 70's. Shame on you costume dept. shame! The exploration of her backstory fit with her motivations. Colin Ferrell as the Penguin/Oz could have been fleshed out a bit more but this could just be a prelude for a second movie. I have been a fan of Jeffery Wright for a long time, going back to before his work with M. Night. His portrayal of Jim Gordan was monumental in that is showed the difficult waters he has to navigate between using the Batman as and ally and "consultant" and the hostilities of the GCPD viewing Batman as a menace and vigilante. I am on the fence about Andy Serkis as Alfred. I felt there was a lot left on the table for this movie and the Alfred character. Peter Sarsgaard's depiction of Gil Colson was lacking. This may just be a set up for introducing Harvey Dent? John Turturro was good as Carmine Falcone. I know there is only so much you can put into a movie so his character development for this movie was adequate and played into the motivations of both Batman and Catwoman. Overall this is a much different take on Batman than the crap of the Clooney and Kilmer batman and darker in nature then the Christopher Nolan Trilogy.

review_text: Okay, first let me start by saying that I have never seen the Twilight series, nor have I seen this actor in anything else. Second, let me inform you that Batman was never my favorite hero. I thought he was okay, but I preferred Superman and even Spider-Man over Batman, so none of that has anything to do with my review here. Now, having said that, I have still seen all the Batman movies with all the different actors. None of them were "great" movies in my opinion. They were just okay. If I had to choose, I would have said Ben Affleck's Batman is my favorite and in my opinion, Batman vs. Superman and Justice League had the best Batman. That was before I saw this movie. This movie, however, is really, really good. This takes place early in Batman's career, 2 years into it, and it is almost a prototype Batman. His suit is more realistic looking, his gadgets are more primitive and he doesn't have an endless supply of different gadgets yet. Even his Batmobile is very basic and more "mobile" than "bat". Commissioner Gordon is not yet the Commissioner of Gotham City. Bruce Wayne himself is still young and is just learning who he is and who The Batman is going to become. And he is one BAD dude! This Batman is angry and doesn't like criminals a whole lot. When he fights, it is deliberate and he fights to take someone down as quickly as possible. There's no playing around. This batman takes no bs from ANYONE, including the police! This movie really captures The Batman's early years and shows him struggling to change from Vengeance to Justice! In all honesty, If ALL the other Batman movies and even the comics had shown these early years of a struggling Batman, he would have been much higher on my favorite superhero list. Even the make-up and wardrobe for the bad guys is by far the most realistic and best I have ever seen. The Cat-Woman has a very primitive costume. The Penguin FINALLY looks like a man AND does still somewhat resemble a penguin somehow. It's amazing. The mob boss is a likable and believable character. The Riddler confused me a little bit at first because to me he looked like Bane, another Batman adversary. But his wardrobe grew on me and I can accept this costume as the Riddler. I don't really have a choice anyway. The crimes and gangs are much more realistic and as a whole, "Sorry Ben Affleck" this is now my favorite Batman movie and favorite Batman to date. I highly recommend buying it. Don't let the gossip about Twilight boy interfere with you watching a good movie. Accept it as the young Batman just starting out and you should love this movie as well. Especially if you are a true Batman fan, which I am not. And as an update: I've had the dvd for about a week now and I've already watched it 5 times. This Batman is just so cool and especially in the beginning when he moves all slow and deliberate, using fear just as much as fighting skills to defeat his enemies! Just buy it already.

The Batman is an honorary tribute to DC's (Detective Comics) roots, reminding us that the Batman is the world's greatest detective, not a superhero. What makes The Batman so unique? Unlike The Dark Night trilogy, The Batman is not a plotless, flashy, battle-filled action movie. The Batman is set in a comic-accurate universe, its dark, gritty, and seeping with corruption waiting to be unveiled. And it is that corruption that gives birth to the Riddler. For those who missed the plot, here's a summary. (SPOILERS) The Wayne family created a Renewal fund for the orphans of Gotham. To the Riddler, who had been an orphan, the Renewal fund had been a beacon of hope. But then he discovered that the Underworld had been leeching off of it and not a single dollar had ever gone to any orphans. This enraged him, and he swore that he would purge Gotham of Underworld scum. Already, the Riddler has a complex backstory and an intriguing moral compass. He is an anti-hero. A product of Gotham. When he discovers that the last living Wayne is the Batman, a fellow anti-hero who had been cleaning the filthy streets of Gotham, he grows obsessed, enamored, delusional. The young Batman also has his own unique character development. And it is refreshingly realistic. He is a social hermit, and his moral compass is growing darker and darker the longer he steeps over his parents death. He defeats crime with an immoral amount of violence. He is a product of Gotham, the dark city.

In general, I feel like The Batman is a solid if not earth-shattering take on a character who's been through countless reinventions. Pros: -Pattison is perfectly serviceable as a young, "year two" Batman. This Bruce Wayne is still finding his footing and though he's a skilled crimefighter, he's still rough around the edges. Pattison does a good job of bringing those insecurities into the picture. - The detective story aspects of the film are a refreshing change from the solves-most-problems-with-fists Batman stories that we usually see. I honestly would like to have seen even more of the riddles, cyphers, etc. being worked into the narrative. - We actually see Bruce/Bats experience some personal growth from the beginning to the end of the film which is always a bonus in superhero films. - Jeffrey Wright is GREAT as Jim Gordon. He pulls off the optimistic yet world-weary vibe with ease and makes the character more personable than even Oldman did (which is saying a lot). Cons - Kravitz does a good job with what she's given, but the Catwoman character falls flat. It feels like the writers tried to shoehorn too much backstory in. With all the baggage she carried, she could have been split into two characters and even then it might have been too much telling and not enough showing. - Serkis is wasted as a ho-hum Alfred. If Catwoman was overloaded with backstory, Alfred has the opposite problem. It's hard to feel that there's any real connection (or reason for connection) between him and Bruce except in one or two minor spots. I would have much preferred the kind of paternal, occasionally skeptical dynamic shown in the Nolan trilogy. - I get that it's one of the darker Batman films tonally, but from a visual / lighting point of view, it's TOO damn dark. Don't get me wrong, I love the lurking-in-the-shadows stuff... but in this case, you mostly just get the shadows. I honestly thought there was something wrong with the projector for the first hour. - We seem to have replaced Bale's Bat-rasp with an entire cast who whisper 85% of their lines. Not a major de-traction, but definitely a notable dis-traction.

review_text: A surprisingly strong “Batman” flick that adds to the genre rather than detracts like many other films, this is worthy enough to belong to the Nolan films. As a reboot, the film may revisit familiar characters but does so in some innovative and interesting new ways. ‘The Batman” focuses on a Gotham again in peril wit the vigilante caped crusader doing thr detective work that was often missing from the more action driven flicks in the various films. Robert Pattinson does a very good job although his Bruce Wayne is a bit more mopey than some previous incarnations. A villain nicknamed The Riddler is causing havoc on Gotham as The Batman tackles corruption in the city of Gotham. Curiously, The Riddler’s victims dovetail with many of the people that Batman is investigating himself. He also has to content with and eventually enlists Selina Kyle. Kyle works for the Falcone organization but has her own motives for wanting to destroy the criminal. Featuring a virtually in recognizable Colin Farrell as the Penguin and Paul Dano as a very different (in the movies) Riddler, this was clearly influenced by Batman: Year One. Matt Reeves who co-wrote the script and directed the film clearly had a creative vision (and it didn’t hurt with Warner thar Reeves had also directed two of the popular “Apes” reboots as well as “Cloverfield” where he demonstrated an ability with genre films with a large scale production). The film did well enough to do a second film and it was critically acclaimed. The film runs too long and could have easily been trimmed by 30 minutes without harming the production. That flaw aside, the film demonstrates that Reeves has the goods to carry on with an interesting variation on the character that is equal to Burton’s and Nolan’s. The Blu-Ray and 4K versions of the film both look and sound exceptional. The only disappointment is that there isn’t a commentary track but the nine featurettes and the nearly hour long making of film does provide plenty of background and trivia on the making of the film. Reeves reboot of Batman does the job admirably. Although the film runs too long, it does have some terrific set pieces and performances from the marvelous supporting cast including Andy Serkis as Alfred and Jeffrey Wright as Gordon.
