Robert Pattinson is the most brooding emo Bruce Wayne and brutal Batman yet! Director Matt Reeves’ superhero, neo-noir, murder mystery, epic The Batman (2022) is certainly one of the greatest films of the year already. The Batman does have intense thrills like Batman beating down gangs of Penguin and Riddler’s henchmen or the Batmobile versus Penguin car chase. But, Reeves has crafted a genuinely depressing, moody murder mystery that finally allows Batman to be the world’s greatest detective on the silver screen. I appreciate Matt Reeves and Peter Craig’s haunting writing. Their vicious Riddler killings are chilling and well orchestrated. You actually wonder what each riddle means in the midst of this crime epic. I cared about all the nuances of political intrigue, illegal dealings, murder clues, and seedy underbelly of Reeves’ Gotham. I love how menacing Gotham feels with anyone coming out of the dark to attack Batman. The Batman feels closer to Zodiac, Se7en, Cure, Blade Runner, The Boston Strangler, or Memories of Murder than other superhero movies out now besides Joker. Reeves directs The Batman to be gritty and dark as he uses shadows as doorways for Batman’s entrance or Wayne manor as Bruce Wayne’s pristine lair of solitude. The Batman is easily the finest film that Matt Reeves has directed to date! Robert Pattinson is enthralling as cinema’s most brooding and emo Bruce Wayne. I loved his haunted expressions, subtle looks, gaunt appearance, and fearsome gravitas in every scene. Pattinson pulls off the forlorn, nihilistic Bruce Wayne narrating and chronicling his nightly ventures as Batman. You feel his despair and fury with each curious gaze at a witness or clue to his brave facing of Batman’s endless foes. Pattinson has gone from romantic teen heartthrob to indie darling to embodying Bruce Wayne’s dark contemplations. He is a phenomenal actor. Robert Pattinson is right up there with Christian Bale and Michael Keaton as my favorite Bruce Wayne. Zoë Kravitz is sultry and sympathetic as Selina Kyle. Her fierce Catwoman feels effortless as she uses her sheer sex appeal to flirt and sneak about as The Cat. I really loved how she made Selina’s character her own with her clear trauma and isolation. You believe Kravitz’ Selina Kyle could love Pattinson’s dejected Batman. Michelle Pfeiffer’s Catwoman remains my favorite incarnation of Selina Kyle’s iconic anti-hero to Batman and love interest for Bruce Wayne. However, Zoë Kravitz feels intimately cautious and fearlessly independent as Catwoman. She is a wonderful actress. Paul Dano’s villain The Riddler is actually scary and intriguing. Dano is ruthless when killing Riddler’s victims and delightful to watch enact his conspiracy enlightening plot upon an unsuspecting Gotham. He is absolutely deranged and delivers a high caliber villain performance for The Batman. Jeffrey Wright is a really cool and intelligent Lieutenant James Gordon. I love how he’s helping solve clues alongside Pattinson’s Batman. John Turturro is a sleazy and underhanded Carmine Falcone. Peter Sarsgaard is great as the creepy and worthless District Attorney Gil Colson. Andy Serkis is great as the supportive and helpful butler Alfred Pennyworth. He feels steadfast and sharp as Alfred right up there with the other classic Alfreds in film. Barry Keoghan’s cameo as The Joker has me curious about where Matt Reeves will go for his sequel. I was hoping Joaquin Phoenix’ Joker would appear opposite Robert Pattinson’s Batman, but maybe that’s just my indie drama fan at heart speaking. Keoghan was brilliant in American Animals and Chernobyl, so I have no doubts about his dramatic acting skills. Editors William Hoy and Tyler Nelson keep you engrossed with striking cuts by Matt Reeves’ stylish direction as The Batman does not feel slow for a behemoth run-time of 176 minutes. Cinematographer Greig Fraser’s stunning shots and careful framing is breathtaking. Many shots made my jaw drop like Batman appearing from the shadows or fog several times to Penguin’s Iceberg Club rave fight. The Batman focuses on Bruce Wayne’s reflective journey of self purpose by day to Batman’s inspiring heroics in the night. Seeing Fraser’s visceral close-ups during conversations is as entertaining and thoughtful as his mesmerizing wide shots during the meticulously choreographed action sequences. I truly was dazzled by the ruthless nature of Pattinson’s brutal hand to hand combat as Batman. Matt Reeves outdid himself really. James Chinlund’s production design makes all these grisly murder scenes and dirty street sets for The Batman. Gotham really looks grim with no hope in sight until the caped crusader’s cowl fades into view. From the constant rainfall like in Se7en to the ever present shadows like old film noir classics, The Batman looks incredible. Art direction from Grant Armstrong, James Lewis, Joe Howard, Gary Jopling, Candice White, Anita Rajkumar, Oliver Benson, Agis Pyrlis, Will Houghton-Connell, Luke Whitelock, and Matthew Kerly looks outstanding. From Penguin’s chaotic club to the watery finale cascaded into dark lights. Matt Reeves’ The Batman is perhaps visually the most creative and dread-inducing of all the pictures starring Gotham’s dark knight. Set decorators David Chow, Laura Ng, Patrick Dunn-Baker, Chris Sanford, Manuel Vilaseca Vaya, Chris Cortner, and James Flanagan’s adorn Wayne manor with precious antiques, while Riddler’s home is overflowing with files and murderous preparations. Every home looked lived in honestly. Visual effects artists Mark Owen Forker, Alex Bicknell, Karen Kelly, Russell Earl, Ben Pickering, Dan Lemmon, Brad Minnich, Loren Robinson, Anders Langlands, Cody Stoof, Simon Butler, Bryan Searing, Julius Lechner, Andrew Kalicki, and Daniel Hazeltine bring The Batman to life. From Batman soaring in Gotham’s dreary night sky to Batman’s Batmobile roaring to life with searing blue flames. The Batman just looks astounding with very realistic CGI. Composer Michael Giacchino’s thunderous score is one that will remain in the minds of every viewer long after seeing The Batman. His bombastic main theme with its groaning melody and frightening eerie atmosphere are genius. I love how the score changes suddenly or fades into existence. The use of Nirvana’s throbbing melancholic song “Something in the Way” is touching and haunting all its own as well. Sound designers Chris Terhune, Andy Nelson, Lee Gilmore, Will Files, Douglas Murray, and Phil Barrie ensure every punch from Batman feels like bricks hitting men to the Batmobile’s screaming engine sounds like it is wailing to life. Costume designers Jacqueline Durran, Dan Blacklock, Rupert Steggle, Lorna Cook, Lizzie Moul, and Steve Wotherspoon create a heavily armored Batsuit for Robert Pattinson as well as sleek gentleman’s suits. Batman’s Batman actually looks protective and cumbersome to move in with a serious presence on screen. I loved all Catwoman’s slick catsuit and fancy dresses and clubwear. Make-up artists Naomi Donne, Doone Forsyth, Samantha Denyer, and Kat Ali craft and paint Colin Farrell into the fat and unsightly Penguin. Their ultra emo aesthetic for Robert Pattinson’s Bruce Wayne is fitting. Their Catwoman make-up is very cute. Overall, The Batman must be seen in theaters to appreciate the powerful score and Matt Reeves’ killer murder mystery. The Batman fulfills Reeves’ promise to make a real neo-noir detective mystery.

Matt Reeves's film "The Batman" is an amazing achievement, but unfortunately falls short in some small but crucial areas. The film is especially important for being the truest portrayal of the essence of the Batman's character and world on film. What do I mean by that? I should start by clarifying that if you mostly know Batman from the movies, or think that Batman only really started with the Frank Miller books of the late 1980s, then you have an incomplete view of the character. From those late 80s books we got the image of Batman as a fantastical monster, gothic and grotesque. And from the movies we have gotten a sort of Baby's First Batman, a summary of the character that necessarily abbreviated and stereotyped in order to produce a popular mainstream film. Setting aside the zany, silly Batman of the mid-40s to mid-60s (about which a whole separate essay could be written), I think the periods which are crucial for grounding the character are the first few years of the character's origin in the early 40s, and the now almost-forgotten Batman comics of the 70s. This 70s period had a gritty street-level approach which reflected the low point at which New York (model for Gotham City and home of DC comics) found itself at the time, and the new trend for messy naturalism which had arisen in American cinema. For a while, Batman even lived in a penthouse apartment and drove a glorified muscle car, as in this movie. In this kind of setting, you get a psychological realism that you don't get in more fanciful versions. And that is something we get in "The Batman" which I don't think we've seen in movies before. For all that Nolan's films are photographed very naturalistically, they are not very realistic in psychological terms. Nolan's Batman is a mythic warrior, Jim Gordon and Alfred are both saints, and the villains seem to be dedicated to evil purely as a matter of principle. Powerful, archetypal stuff, maybe, but not relatable. "The Batman", by contrast, has a very stylised colour pallet, but its characters are more grounded than we've seen before. Previously, Bruce's psychological trauma was something to occasionally reference, but here all that had been hinted at is made explicit: it's easy to say that Batman is driven by trauma, but here we see that trauma etched into the character's face, embodied in the huddled, defensive way he holds himself, and the way he talks as though he is unused to verbal communication and human relationships. It's a revelation to see this state of mind revealed rather than paid lip service to. Suddenly the existence of the character could almost make sense in the real world. And Jim Gordon is no longer impossibly good, noble and wise, somehow on a god-like level compared to the cops with whom he serves. This Gordon is hardened, streetwise, tightly wound, and fully familiar with the organisational politics of the police. I'd also like to mention Falcone, who is not in the movie a lot, but who eventually is revealed as a crucial player in the story. The more we learn about his involvement in the story, the more layers of his character come to light. The complexity of his character is perhaps the greatest mystery which Batman solves in the course of the film. All the performances in the film are excellent. I was even impressed with Zoe Kravitz after being disappointed by her in the High Fidelity TV series. Colin Farrell as the Penguin works in the role, though he plays a surprisingly small part in the film, and I do still wonder why we got a young-ish actor in (very convincing) old-age make-up, when there are plenty of good older actors who could do the part without prosthetics. The actors playing the cops and crooked politicians were all very effective in their parts. The Batman costume caused some controversy after being revealed in the trailers, but as used in the movie it doesn't raise an eyebrow. It is effective and right for the world of this film. I enjoyed the technical enhancements this new suit contained, and was only disappointed that they weren't more used later in the film. The Batman's car is a powerful presence in the movie, being frighteningly aggressive and unpredictable in a way which matches the personality of its owner. As presented in the film, it really does have a persona in a way that makes previous Batmobiles look merely like fancy cars. Script, photography, editing. It's hard to separate these elements out, as they always seem to be working together in perfect unison. The amount of cinematic craft put into this film is impressive by how concentrated it is in execution and how total it is in effect. Every scene, and almost every shot, seems to say something powerful about how we relate to each other, about power, exploitation, vulnerability and isolation. Further, the script explores elements of the Batman story which seem so obvious and powerful in hindsight that one wonders why they weren't addressed on screen before. I'm talking about the question which any person who wields any sort of power must ultimately answer to themselves: is it better to provoke fear or inspire hope? The script goes beyond a simple "naive niceness versus Machiavellian realpolitik" dichotomy, to look at the way strong personal examples inevitably influence others, whether for good or for bad, in ways that can't always be predicted. The music has provoked comment from all who've seen the film, and I will be no exception. The "Batman" musical motif (it is too simple to be called a theme) becomes incredibly powerful just by careful repetition during the course of the film. The way it is used really is a stroke of genius. However, rest of the soundtrack is less innovative, but still effective. Sound design is good - but home viewers are warned that they will need to boost the bass to understand the impact that the cinematic experience had. Watching on a laptop computer probably won't cut it. Thus far I have mostly lavished praise on this film, but there are a couple of issues which I think have a negative effect. The first issue is that there are some moments of inadvertent silliness which undermine the drama. One example is the odd woollen mask that the Cat wears. I am aware that it was in one of the comics, but in real life it just looks daft. Another moment takes place after the car chase that is the climax of the first half of the film. The way Batman peers down to look at Penguin just looks comical, though it's obviously meant to be impressive. The second issue, which has been much commented on, is the length and pacing of the film. Setting aside the issue of bladder control, when we talk about a film's length being a problem, what we are really talking about is a matter of structure and tone. There are parts of the movie where the use of deliberate pacing is brilliant - but in other areas a quicker pace is needed, if only for the sake of contrast with those slower parts. A structure without contrast can create a monotonous tone, which can leave the audience feeling exhausted and beyond that even bored. I think that may be why people's attention begins to wander during the film's climax. There might also be the issue of the director himself becoming exhausted, as the climactic fight is not as visually interesting as action scenes earlier in the film. It could also be argued that the sequence ends with a series of "wow" moments which are each impressive in themselves, but they are piled up so many upon each other that the effect becomes bathetic. A few well-spaced climactic moments will inevitably be more effective than an apparently endless series of climaxes one after the other. The next criticism I will make is that the romance seemed unnecessary and unconvincing. I thought we were past the era of movies forcing romance into films where it's not needed, but apparently I was wrong. This element might still have worked if the actors had 'chemistry', but sadly they have none. They try but the result is not believable. Instead the romance contributes to the film's pacing issues, adding nothing to the story while taking up valuable screen time. It is especially a problem for the film's ending. It really should have ended with the shot of Batman looking up at the helicopter, this moment signifying the conclusion of his story arc. Instead, this powerful moment is undermined by a Riddler scene that teases a sequel, followed by a scene of the Bat and the Cat saying farewell, which is both structurally unnecessary and, thanks to the lack of chemistry, boring. So the movie really ends with a thud. If these scenes were going to be kept in the movie, they really should have been a post-credits bonus, not part of the main film. In terms of audience reaction, the response has been surprisingly divided, but reading the one-star reviews gives the impression that some people are not able to understand the film. It seems they just can't cope with the emphasis on mood and character, and a hero who isn't a wise-cracking he-man. To put all the above criticisms in context, I'd like to set this film beside the recent films of Denis Villeneuve. Villeneuve has received a lot of praise for his films of Blade Runner 2049 and Dune, but I think he has been overrated. He is certainly a very strong visual director with an acute sense of detail. However, I find his films cold and hollow, concerned with style for the sake of it, and with not much meaning beneath the surface. There are also some rather silly story and character elements which he covers up by means of immense grandiosity of execution. Reeves doesn't have quite the extreme control of detail that Villeneuve has. On the other hand, he has something to say. As I said above, every part of "The Batman" is suffused with meaning - and not the abstract, mythical meaning of fantasy, but meaning essentially concerned with what people are like, and how we relate to each other. And where Reeves has fallen short, at least he did so while taking a big swing. In what might be the peak of his career, he has created something unique: he has created the truest Batman movie that has ever been seen. I suspect this achievement will last for some time to come, and we should be thankful for it.

review_text: This is a long (almost 3 hours) movie that could have been shortened because at times it felt a little draggy. The only justification for its length is that it probably enhanced the dark, gloomy atmosphere in which the plot depended. The main villain is The Riddler, played superbly by Paul Dano (although his real face was revealed only towards the end, but what a character. Pattison as Batman? The jury will be split for sure - just as whether Brad Pitt made a good Achilles. The Riddler, in this movie, set out to kill important people including the DA and the police commisioner, while also targetting Bruce Wayne, whose father appears (according to the Riddler) was connected to the assasinated people. Zoe Kravitz and Colin Farrell were excellent support as Catwoman and the Penguin respectively. Farrell is almost unrecognisable, but is probably the next best actor after Paul Dano in this film. A long but good movie.

Batman is my favorite superhero and I am glad they adapted him right. The Batman is a serious noir detective film. They did not turn it in to a comedy, like what another studio would have done and ruin the tone from the source material. The movie has a good long length of time to tell a good story and develop the characters. Also two great bonus scenes that I wish were in the movie. The movie has everything you could want in a Batman story, like new gadgets, a Batman suit which looks like it is based off on the Arkham knight. The Arkham knight is my favorite Batman game so that’s extra points for me. They are parts of the movie that reference Batman comic books that I also liked, Batman fans will know which ones. The action scenes, the acting, the music, the cinematography were all great. Batman has a sweet new bat mobile as well. I bought the LEGO version just so I could put it together, it was fun every step of the way. I am glad the riddler got a chance to shine as the main villain instead of the joker again. Dino did a great job with that role. I always knew he would because I saw him act in the movie their will be blood. The only thing bad to say and I am just nitpicking is I wish the action scenes were a little bitter longer because they are so good. I think this movie is on the same level as the dark knight, but The dark knight is still the best Batman movie, I don’t know if it could ever be topped. The bottom line is this is an amazing movie, that every Batman fan should have.
